entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price, in order to capitalize on the trade. The context assumes three key players: Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator.Mary the Maker publishes a limit order to buy a derivative. Bob, the bulletin board operator, has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob doesn't want to execute, he relays the order to Terry the Taker and other subscribers to Bob's market. Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's limit order. If Terry decides not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.The concern raised is that this model starts to resemble a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure. It is suggested that Terry should open his own brokerage (bulletin board) and compete on quoting prices with Bob. This competition between Bob and Terry can lead to better execution quality and draw more market activity.The issue of front-running is considered a good problem to have as it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market. It is argued that finding what products people are interested in trading and providing them with a good user experience is more important. The suggestion is to focus on user experience and let everything else fall in line.Different security paradigms are discussed to mitigate front-running risks. One approach is to duplicate the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitor latency anomalies. Another approach is to run the bulletin boards as a federation, using techniques like Honey Badger BFT, where incoming board offers become consensus items. These approaches aim to address front-running concerns and ensure fair trading.The overall goal of the CivKit framework is to create a flexible peer-to-peer marketplace that can adapt to different types of trades and market participants' tolerance for front-running risks. The configuration of parameters related to front-running resistance will depend on real-world deployments.The discussion also touches upon the idea of a Web-of-Stakes, which assigns economic weight to market entities based on reputation. This reputation framework can be combined with decentralized identifier techniques to create a reliable scoring system for trades, counterparties, and service operators.A group of researchers, including Nicholas Gregory and Ray Youssef, is working on a peer-to-peer market system that aims to enable censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design combines the Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing infrastructure to provide a high level of confidentiality to market participants. The market boards operate as Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway, functioning autonomously and in competition with each other.Trades in this system are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, relying on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication. To enable the scoring of trades, counterparties, and service operators, the researchers propose the use of a Web-of-Stakes, which assigns an economic weight to each market entity based on the Bitcoin UTXO set. This reputation paradigm can be combined with decentralized identifiers using state-of-the-art Web-of-Trust techniques.The researchers also propose a consistent incentive framework for service operators through privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments. This framework incentivizes efficiency similar to routing hops on the Lightning network and miners on the Bitcoin base layer.The whitepaper delves into the architecture of the system, combining the Nostr and Lightning technologies. The team plans to release code and modules built on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. They aim to collaborate with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients, taking into account long-term thinking.Feedback on the project is highly encouraged, as the team welcomes input from the community. The paper can be found at the provided link [3], along with additional resources such as the Lightning Dev Kit [4] and the Nostr libraries. The researchers are excited about the opportunity to work together with the community to advance the field of peer-to-peer marketplaces and establish decentralized standards.
